title.narrative: Remodeling National Health Building Kampala. UG-KAMPALA-National Health BDNG**ADD WORK**. SURCHARGES CONTRACT 19GE5018C0041. Other Services - Design Fees and Construction. Miscellaneous/Other Contractual Services - WCF Surcharges. Other Services - Design Fees and Construction (FAS)

description.narrative: Reduce the transmission and impact of HIV/AIDS through support for prevention, care and treatment programs.

This award strives to reduce the transmission and impact of HIVAIDS through support for prevention, care and treatment programs. More specifically, this includes Remodeling National Health Building Kampala[Covers payments of reimbursable value added taxes on purchases as required, e.g., in European Common Market countries.]. Construction services required for the remodeling of the national Health Building (NHL) in Butabika, Kampala, Uganda. The existing building is a 5-story office and laboratory building located just across the street from Butabika hospital, in the outskirts of the capital city of Kampala.. Remodeling National Health Building Kampala [Covers the costs for receiving, inspecting, stocking, pulling from stock, delivery, and other related services such as the 1 percent acquisition surcharge for executing grants and contracts above post warrant levels.]. Remodeling National Health Building Kampala [Covers costs of design fees and construction of exhibits and stands (FAS annual marketing plans/projects).]. Remodeling National Health Building Kampala. participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: Uganda is a key strategic partner for the United States, particularly with regard to regional stabilization. The United States employs a wide-ranging approach to foreign assistance in Uganda based on diverse economic, political, and security interests. Given its role as a regional stabilizer, the United States has consistently worked with the Government of Uganda (GOU) to resolve regional security threats and conflicts. U.S. support is critical for enabling democratic institutions to function effectively and for fostering more sustainable and equitable national development - elements that are essential to both short and long-term stability in the East Africa region. To achieve these objectives, U.S. assistance includes: promoting good governance, human rights, and multi-party democracy; addressing key health threats, including HIV/AIDS and malaria, through improved service delivery under the Global Health Initiative (GHI); supporting Uganda's National Development Plan in improving agricultural productivity, food security and nutrition through the Feed the Future (FTF) initiative; professionalizing the police and military; and addressing critical environmental issues, including global climate change and biodiversity.
